title: Congress Passes Two-Day Spending Bill
summary: Short-term bill would fund government through Dec. 20 as negotiations continue over coronavirus relief package. WASHINGTON-President Trump signed a two-day spending bill passed by Congress Friday evening averting a partial government shutdown after midnight, as congressional leaders struggled to wrap up negotiations on a coronavirus relief package.

title: Some Cryptocurrency Disclosure Required in Proposals
summary: Treasury Department seeks to hold users to standards followed by traditional financial institutions. The Treasury Department unveiled a plan Friday to require some cryptocurrency traders to provide information about their identities in an effort to curb the anonymous transfer of assets by criminals using the new technology.

title: Moderna's Covid-19 Vaccine Is Cleared for American Use
summary: Vaccinations with the shot, the second to gain FDA permission, could start as soon as Monday. U.S. health regulators on Friday permitted use of Moderna Inc.'s Covid-19 vaccine, the second shot to get the green light to help end the deadliest pandemic in more than a century.

title: Moderna, Exxon, Alphabet, Amazon: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose stocks moved on the week's business news. U.S. health regulators late Friday permitted use of Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine, the second shot to get the green light to help end the pandemic. The Food and Drug Administration's authorization comes a week after the agency authorized the first shot in the U.S., from Pfizer Inc. and its partner BioNTech SE. Moderna, a ten-year-old biotech that has never had a product cleared by the FDA, expects to deliver a total of 20 million doses by the end of December. Moderna shares rose 5.1% Thursday when an advisory panel cleared the way for Friday night's authorization.

title: Moderna Shot Expected to Bolster U.S. Vaccine Efforts
summary: The vaccine can be more easily shipped and handled than Pfizer's, helping smaller hospitals and rural areas overcome logistical hurdles. Health officials across the U.S. are counting on the arrival of a second Covid-19 vaccine to boost scarce supplies and sidestep logistical issues encountered by the first vaccine, which began distribution this week.

title: Moderna's Covid-19 Vaccine: When Can You Get It and How Effective Is It?
summary: People could start getting doses within days, though it would take well into 2021 for most to get access. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration authorized a Covid-19 vaccine from Moderna Inc., the second shot to gain the thumbs-up required to start going into distribution. Here's what we know and don't know.

title: Fiat Chrysler's Mike Manley to Lead Americas After Merger
summary: North American operations of Fiat Chrysler have offset losses racked up in other parts of world. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV Chief Executive Officer Mike Manley will become head of the Americas following the Italian-American company's merger with France's PSA Group, ensuring the new entity can leverage the veteran executive's experience.

title: Fed Says Banks Can Withstand Pandemic
summary: Banks are allowed to restart share buybacks, with limits, as central bank continues to cap dividends. The Federal Reserve said Friday that the largest U.S. banks remain strong enough to survive the coronavirus crisis but warned that a prolonged economic downturn could saddle them with hundreds of billions of dollars in losses on soured loans.

title: New Ad Fraud Scheme Highlights a Growing Problem for Streaming TV
summary: Oracle says it detected a continuing effort to lure ad dollars with simulated devices and apps. Oracle Corp.'s data cloud and measurement business said it detected a new instance of fraud in streaming television that likely impacted millions of dollars in advertising spending, signaling a growing problem for advertisers as they move more dollars into the medium.

title: Christopher Waller Sworn In as Newest Fed Governor
summary: The economist becomes the fifth member of the body nominated to his or her current position by President Trump.

title: Federal Covid-19 Vaccinations Begin in Nursing Homes
summary: CVS, Walgreens administer doses at long-term care facilities in three states. A federal effort to administer Covid-19 vaccines to workers and residents in long-term care facilities began Friday in Connecticut, Florida and Ohio, with a broader rollout in a dozen states set to start Monday.

title: Beijing Tests Joe Biden
summary: Will the President-elect speak up about China's jailing of Jimmy Lai?. No one should mistake what the jailing of Jimmy Lai and other Hong Kong champions of democracy signals: China is testing Joe Biden.

title: The Court Stands on Principle
summary: The Justices toss a census case ginned up by Democratic states.. The fuss over President Trump's order to exclude undocumented immigrants from the decennial reapportionment may be much ado about nothing. That's essentially what a 6-3 majority on the Supreme Court said Friday in dismissing a legal challenge (Trump v. New York) by Democratic states for lack of standing.

title: Russia's SolarWinds Hack
summary: Are U.S. cyber defenses the equivalent of the Maginot Line in 1940?. You know a security breach is bad when no one in government wants to talk about it. That appears to be the case with what is being called a Russian cyber attack on at least six U.S. cabinet-level departments that has come to light in the last week.

title: Zoom Executive Charged With Disrupting Tiananmen Memorials
summary: U.S. prosecutors say Xinjiang Jin worked with Chinese intelligence in a case highlighting the challenge of operating in the U.S. and China. Federal prosecutors charged a China-based executive at U.S. company Zoom Video Communications Inc. with conspiring to disrupt videoconference commemorations of the crackdown on the 1989 Tiananmen Square democracy protests.

title: 'The Knowledge Machine' Review: Science's Stubborn Majesty
summary: Why the 'iron apparatus' of the scientific method counts for more than any single genius.. Among the missed opportunities in my life, the elaborate physics kit my parents gave me for my 10th birthday reigns supreme. Intimidated by the sheer number of parts, I never performed any of the experiments, but I remember being mightily pleased with the manual that came with it, a spiral-bound paean to the rigors of scientific tinkering.

title: Nike Powers Through Pandemic With Digital Push
summary: Sportswear giant reports higher profit and revenue, boosted by China and 84% jump in digital sales. Nike Inc.'s pivot to e-commerce has helped the sneaker giant power through the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Cred Avoids Trustee Takeover, Faces Examiner's Probe
summary: A bankruptcy judge admonished the company's two owners not to interfere with its independent leadership. A bankruptcy judge declined to place cryptocurrency platform Cred Inc. under the control of an outside trustee but ordered an examination of how and why the company failed.

title: A California Plan to Chase Away the Rich, Then Keep Stalking Them
summary: A proposed wealth tax would apply for a decade to anyone who spends 60 days in the state in a single year.. California's Legislature is considering a wealth tax on residents, part-year residents, and any person who spends more than 60 days inside the state's borders in a single year. Even those who move out of state would continue to be subject to the tax for a decade-a provision that calls to mind the Eagles' famous "Hotel California" lyric: "You can check out any time you like, but you can never leave."

title: Biden Is a Climate Dead End
summary: Green pork will do less good than getting out of the way for energy technology and investment.. Find a spot on your refrigerator for a quote Vice President-elect Kamala Harris made shortly before the election. "Do you believe climate change is happening and threatening the air we breathe and the water that we drink?" That is, having invoked the sacred term, she proceeded to evince zero understanding of what the issue is all about. Her careless rhetoric is more representative than you might think.

title: Politics: The Experts Versus the Pandemic
summary: In the fight to control Covid-19, public fears and policymakers' hubris make a powerful combination.. It's easy to lament, as Nicholas Christakis does several times in "Apollo's Arrow: The Profound and Enduring Impact of Coronavirus on the Way We Live" (Little, Brown Spark, 368 pages, $29), how quickly the Covid-19 pandemic was "politicized." But politics is fundamentally about how people live peaceably with each other. Any corporate response to a disease involves power and compulsion and is, by definition, political.

title: 'Intimations' Review: Scenes from a Global Humbling
summary: From solitary suffering to madness in company, Zadie Smith traces the pandemic's marks on the human heart.. It is rare, in the midst of an experience, to become conscious of it as such-as a thing that will shape us, mark us, mean something. Usually we are too caught up in the current; we have to climb up on the bank and dry off before we can begin to see that the experience-just then, just there-changed us. But sometimes a moment comes along, in our private lives or our collective ones, that overwhelms us immediately with the awareness of its being a thing that matters. This year, from the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, has been that sort of moment, surreally extended and bloated, composed of a cascade of mini-moments too rapid to process. What does it mean? we've sputtered as it hit us. Where will it leave its mark on us (individually, collectively)? How will it appear when we look back on it years from now?

title: 'Cyberpunk 2077' Is Taken Off PlayStation Store
summary: Videogame developer plans to release major updates in January, February. Sony Corp. pulled "Cyberpunk 2077" from its PlayStation Store after a wave of user complaints, as one of the holiday season's most anticipated videogame releases risked becoming one of the industry's most spectacular flops.

title: New York Times Points to Problems With Its 'Caliphate' Podcast
summary: Publication says in lengthy editor's note that insufficient checking was 'institutional failing'. The New York Times on Friday repudiated its prominent 2018 podcast titled "Caliphate" that featured an alleged Islamic State executioner and will reassign Rukmini Callimachi, the reporter who led the series.

title: Google Offers Staff Weekly At-Home Covid-19 Testing
summary: Search giant rolls out testing to work-from-home staff; website crashes. Google has come up with a new perk for Silicon Valley's famously pampered workforce: Free, weekly, at-home Covid-19 testing.

title: Chip Shortage Slows Global Auto Recovery
summary: Volkswagen plans to curb production as chip makers struggle to meet demand, pointing to potentially uneven economic rebound next year. BERLIN- Volkswagen AG said it would cut production in the first quarter in China, Europe and North America because of a shortage of chips, the latest evidence that chip production is straining to meet demand after pandemic-related cuts earlier this year.

title: Stocks Slip to End Week as Stimulus Talks Continue
summary: Major indexes still gain for the week though as lawmakers continue to discuss coronavirus relief. U.S. stocks edged lower Friday but notched weekly gains, as investors tracked developments on a coronavirus aid package.

title: Biden Team Says It Is Facing Transition 'Resistance' from Pentagon
summary: Pentagon says it wanted a 'pause' in transition meetings for the holidays. President-elect Joe Biden's transition team said it was informed Thursday that meetings with the Defense Department were being put on hold, adding it had met with "isolated resistance" in some parts of the government ahead of the Jan. 20 inauguration.

title: Watchdog Finds Some VA Hospitals Rationed or Ran Out of PPE
summary: Nearly two dozen VA emergency rooms or urgent-care centers had to ration gear earlier this year, and two ran out of some equipment.. Nearly two dozen emergency rooms or urgent-care centers at Department of Veterans Affairs hospitals had to ration personal-protective equipment earlier this year, and two ran out of some gear, according to an internal watchdog report released Friday.

title: NYPD Faulted in Handling of George Floyd Protests
summary: Watchdog agency said officers' actions heightened tensions at demonstrations. The New York Police Department mishandled its response to the Black Lives Matter demonstrations that took place in New York City after the May 25 police killing of George Floyd, deploying officers with insufficient protest training and relying on crowd-control tactics that at times heightened tensions, a city watchdog agency said in a report Friday.

title: The Martini's Contribution to Civilization
summary: The cocktail was invented in the U.S., but it soon became a worldwide symbol of sophistication.. Historian Amanda Foreman searches the past for the origins of today's world. Read previous columns here.

title: Lee Raymond to Leave JPMorgan's Board
summary: Former Exxon Mobil chief has been lead independent director at the bank since 2001. JPMorgan Chase & Co. on Friday said Lee Raymond, its longtime lead independent director and the recent target of a vote-out campaign over climate-change concerns, is leaving the board at the end of the year.

title: Pence Gets Covid-19 Vaccine Amid Immunization Campaign
summary: Top administration officials weigh setting example against appearing privileged. Vice President Mike Pence was administered the Covid-19 vaccine in a televised event Friday, becoming the senior-most member of the Trump administration known to have received the shot.

title: United Airlines Reacts to Possible Covid-19 Death
summary: Aim is to contact passengers on flight that was diverted Monday for medical emergency. United Airlines Holdings Inc. said it is providing information to health officials so they can reach passengers who might have been exposed to Covid-19 on a recent flight.

title: Google's Trial in Justice Department's Antitrust Case Set for September 2023
summary: DOJ case now involves 14 states; new lawsuit by 35 other states could land on same schedule. WASHINGTON-Government antitrust cases challenging Google's business practices are going to be a long road in court.

title: Fed's Kaplan Says It Will Be Time to Taper Bond Buying When Economy Is Clearly Recovering
summary: The Dallas Fed president said he remains concerned extended periods of bond buying could bring problems. Reserve Bank of Dallas President Robert Kaplan said Friday that he believes it will be time for the central bank to start pulling back on its bond-buying stimulus efforts when it is clear the economy is recovering strongly.

title: Present Company Included (Saturday Crossword, December 19)
The Journal Acrostic (Saturday, December 19)
Covid-19 Vaccine Advice Leaves Some People With Allergies in Limbo
summary: FDA and CDC advise certain patients to skip Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, while U.K.'s broader warning sows concern. Severe allergy sufferers say they are confused about whether they should get the Covid-19 vaccine made by Pfizer Inc. and BioNTech SE , and public-health authorities on both sides of the Atlantic are offering conflicting advice.

title: BuzzFeed, Axios Among Digital Media Players Eyeing Deals
summary: Big players explore acquiring rivals and going public through blank-check companies. Momentum is building toward consolidation in the digital media sector as big and small players alike look for potential combinations.

title: Hawaii Opens to Tourists Again, but Beware the Covid Hurdles
summary: The Aloha State relaxed its entry regulations in the fall, but the pandemic rules are stricter than in most other states and change frequently. HAWAII REMAINED a paradisiacal bubble of plumy palms and pulsing surf for much of the coronavirus pandemic. The statewide mandatory 14-day visitor quarantine enacted March 26 all but halted tourism, curbing visitor arrival to the islands from 30,000 daily to fewer than 500. Now, nine months later, the state boasts the lowest average daily case count in the country, but it's also suffering from the highest unemployment rate in America. After months of reopening delays, Hawaii relaxed travel rules in October to slowly restart tourism, the state's main economic engine. If you're tempted to jet off to the Aloha State, however, be wary. The road to Paradise comes with a few hurdles.

title: Aluminum Prices Push Toward 2020 High
summary: The metal has gained more than 13% year-to-date. Aluminum prices are trading near their highest levels in almost two years, fueled by soaring demand for raw materials and worries that potential new U.S. sanctions on one of the world's largest producers could limit global supplies of the metal.

title: Supreme Court Puts Off Ruling on Whether Census Should Count Immigrants in U.S. Illegally
summary: Trump administration wanted to exclude group from population count, which is used for congressional redistricting. WASHINGTON-A divided Supreme Court dismissed a challenge to President Trump's plan to exclude immigrants in the U.S. illegally from the counts used to determine congressional seats, with the conservative majority saying it was premature to rule before it was clear that the outgoing administration could implement the policy.

title: Potential for Monetary Award in Anti-Money Laundering Whistleblower Program Draws Concerns
summary: Some companies say prospect of financial benefit to compliance professionals for reporting possible violations could weaken compliance programs. A new anti-money-laundering whistleblower award program may allow individuals with internal compliance or audit responsibilities to report possible violations to the regulators for bounties, raising concerns among some companies.

title: Olive Garden, Other Chains Suffer New Losses Amid Covid-19 Surge
summary: New dining restrictions hurt Darden, Starbucks, Brinker. Restaurant chains are showing signs of fresh stress this week as the latest coronavirus surge fuels new sales losses.

title: NYC to Drop Academic Criteria for In-Demand Middle-School Admissions
summary: The new application process, slated to last one year, was spurred by the pandemic's erasure of some measures used to judge student performance. New York City said it would drop academic criteria for middle-school admissions for one year in favor of lotteries for sought-after schools, a new application process spurred by the pandemic's erasure of some measures used to judge student performance.

title: Obama Wins Another Round Against Community Organizers
summary: The former president should thank the current one for helping him build in Chicago.. Community organizers seeking to prevent former President Barack Obama from erecting a 235-foot tower in a Chicago park have been bulldozed again.

title: An Album to Liberate a Genre
summary: 'Free Jazz: A Collective Improvisation by the Ornette Coleman Double Quartet' was and remains a radical recording thanks to an unencumbered exchange of sonic ideas among a bevy of talented musicians..

title: William Barr: 'One Standard of Justice'
summary: The departing attorney general talks about John Durham, Robert Mueller, Hunter Biden, Mike Flynn and the flak he's taken from both parties.. The U.S. attorney general is meditating on one of his frustrations with the modern Justice Department: The outside world keeps moving faster; the wheels of justice ever more slowly. "Nobody wants to take responsibility anymore," William Barr says with a hint of incredulity. "They wring their hands and push issues around the bureaucracy and trade memos for months." His response: "Bring it to me! I'll make the decision. That's what I'm here for!"

title: Scenes From Pompeii-or Maybe My Abandoned Manhattan Office
summary: Notes, empty yogurt containers-all left behind in March as colleagues fled. Will we return soon?. New York

title: Santa Claus Is the Original Bagholder
summary: 'Tis the season to cash in some stock-market winnings on bullish day-trader swag. While "Black Friday" might have a completely different meaning to speculators than to shoppers, 'tis still the season for that day trader in your life.

title: The Unsettling Confrontations of Artist Yoshitomo Nara
summary: Two U.S. exhibitions explore the work of the Japanese artist, who combines childlike cuteness with adult anger and pain.. Posed against a blank background, the girl stares up at us like a small child. Her enormous head, small body and wide-open eyes signal "adorable." Her vulnerability triggers our protective instincts.

title: For Many Big Businesses, 2020 Was a Surprisingly Good Year
summary: Resume Subscription. The coronavirus pandemic brought the global economy to a screeching halt this spring, sparking fears of a corporate bloodbath. As the year ends, it's clear that the crisis has rewired the economy in surprising ways and served up unexpected opportunities for some big businesses to prosper.

title: Hack Tests the Limits of U.S. Response
summary: It appears spying, not destruction, was the aim; U.S. officials have yet to define precise impact of the suspected Kremlin intrusion. WASHINGTON-Despite its size, a sprawling computer hack blamed on Russia could leave President Trump and the incoming Biden administration struggling to find the right response, former U.S. cybersecurity officials and experts said.

title: What to Do Before You Die: A Tech Checklist
summary: What happens to your Facebook and Google accounts-and other digital stuff-when you die? Nothing if you don't make a plan.. Earlier this year, I recorded my mother talking about her life.

title: 'Mozart' Review: The Composer as Novelist
summary: Mozart may be famed as a prodigy, but Jan Swafford celebrates his apprehension of humanity in full.. One January night in 1761, little Wolfgang Mozart insisted on playing a challenging harpsichord piece he had just heard performed by his older sister, already a virtuoso. He had never played a keyboard before. At the beginning of "Mozart: The Reign of Love" (don't let the sappy subtitle put you off), the esteemed composer and biographer Jan Swafford writes:

title: Foundation Chief Andrew Delbanco Wants All Students to Wrestle With Great Books
summary: The professor and author hopes to expand humanities offerings on campus, even for scientists and engineers. Andrew Delbanco recalls teaching a class about Abraham Lincoln at Columbia University several years ago and having a student challenge his regard for the Gettysburg Address. The young Black woman wondered how he could expect her to share his respect for a Civil War speech that never mentioned slavery. "That's a really hard question," Mr. Delbanco says.

title: Mysteries: Locking Up the Lincoln Lawyer
summary: Mickey Haller is back, but instead of working from his car, he's in a cell.. "No one is ever found innocent in a court of law," says Mickey Haller, the "Lincoln Lawyer" who works out of the back seat of his car and narrates Michael Connelly's Los Angeles-set novel "The Law of Innocence" (Little, Brown, 423 pages, $29). "The justice system can only deliver a verdict of guilty or not guilty. . . . The law of innocence is unwritten."

title: After Universal Music, What Will Vivendi's Encore Be?
summary: Shareholders have little choice but to trust billionaire backer Vincent Bolloré as the French media giant slowly moves toward an IPO of its most successful asset. While the pandemic has silenced concert halls around the globe this year, the world's largest music companies have had plenty of excuses to party. The latest is Chinese tech giant Tencent's move to double its 10% stake in Universal Music Group.

title: Ivy League Colleges Report Dramatic Growth in Early-Admission Applicant Pools
summary: Columbia received 49% more applications than last year; Harvard had 57% rise while admitting smaller cohort. Early-admission applications to Ivy League colleges skyrocketed this year, as anxious high-school seniors tried to boost their chances of getting into some of the most selective schools in the country.

title: Investors Risk Over-Ordering Restaurant Stocks
summary: Wall Street is unconcerned by falling sales, but might be placing too much faith in a rosy spring. A dark winter for the dining industry hasn't scared off stockholders in restaurant chains. But a roaring spring is needed to validate that faith.

title: Fiction: Uncanny Revolutions
summary: A tale of conspiracy and dreams, a story of high-stakes board games and a catalog of fools.. 'Ah, revolution . . .' sighs the beleaguered heroine of "Peach Blossom Paradise" (NYRB, 377 pages, $17.95) by Chinese writer Ge Fei. "Revolution is when no one has any idea what they're doing. You know you're making revolution, it's true, but you have absolutely no idea what's going on." The novel, the first volume of Mr. Ge's Jiangnan Trilogy, takes place at the start of the 20th century during the lawless final years of the Qing Dynasty, and although the Xinhai Revolution and the establishment of the Republic of China provide it backdrop, this sinuous, captivating epic is less interested in textbook history than in the madness and illusions that underwrite it.

title: 'Wild Minds' Review: Animation's Golden Age
summary: In playful abstractions and sumptuous fantasies, a generation of animators explored the subversive possibilities of cartoons.. Five years ago, Reid Mitenbuler penned "Bourbon Empire," about the business of liquor. It's only fitting that his new book is on animation history, since both subjects are the stuff that dreams and nightmares are made of. In the toon industry's past, distilled spirits frequently stimulated anthropomorphic conjuring.

title: One Way to Say Good Riddance to 2020? Light Your Planner on Fire
summary: Lots of people can't wait to say good riddance to 2020. Some are planning a flaming farewell; 'close out this hellscape year'. To cap off Anneliese Place's "dumpster fire" of a year, she's seeking catharsis through an original ritual: burning her 2020 planner.

title: For NASA, It Should Be Mars or Bust
summary: After decades of nostalgia for the Apollo program, it's time for NASA to send astronauts on a radical new adventure, worthy of America's pioneering spirit.

title: 'The Janus Point' Review: Double Time
summary: A new theory of the nature of time rethinks the Big Bang not as an origin, but a midpoint.. The author describes this book as "a song of thanks to the cosmos." It's not the catchiest of tunes and the melody requires a little puzzling out, but it's worth the effort because Julian Barbour's theme is the greatest mystery in physics: the nature of time.

title: Five Best: Memoirs of the Scottish Highlands
summary: Selected by Annalena McAfee, author of the novel 'Nightshade.'. By Gavin Maxwell (1960)

title: 'Heinrich Heine' Review: Song of the Outsider
summary: A passionate champion of German language and legend, he was prescient about the historical nightmares to come.. For Nazi censors in the 1930s, "Die Lorelei" presented a special problem. One of the best-known German poems, it tells of a maiden who sits on a mountaintop overlooking the Rhine, combing her golden hair and singing a melody so enchanting that sailors below are transfixed and shipwrecked. "Die Lorelei" had been sung as a folk song for a hundred years, and it could hardly be omitted from verse anthologies. But its author was Jewish, which made it impossible for him to appear in a Nazi-approved book. As a compromise, the poem was credited to "Anonymous."

title: Children's Books: One Famous Fox
summary: The tricky figure of Reynard carries with him the flavor of an older and wilder world of story.. So far as we know, the fox as a wicked and tricky character type originated 2,500 years ago with Aesop. As with other animals in the old moralist's fables, the fox embodied human characteristics: pride, appetite, cunning. After the turn of the first millennium, Aesop's fox acquired a name and began to catch on in Europe. He turned up in a 12th-century Latin poem composed (probably) by a Flemish monk. Soon after he figured in the Old French satirical tales of "Le Roman de Renart," becoming so popular that the word for "fox" in French changed from goupil to renard. Reynard popped up in Low German (in the narrative poem "Reinhart Fuchs") and Middle Dutch (in the verses of "Van den vos Reinarde") and achieved lasting fame in English thanks to William Caxton's rollicking 1481 translation from the Dutch, which became one of the first bestsellers in history.

title: Slow Down the Campaign Against Facebook
summary: Why is the government targeting Big Tech? 'Because that's where the money is.'. Your editorial "Breaking Up Facebook" (Dec. 11) brings to mind the Radio Corporation of America. In the late 1950s Congress decided to go after the RCA, a global company that was dominant in the consumer electronics business. As part of a 1958 consent decree, suddenly anybody could license RCA patents at no cost. No domestic company of any consequence took up the offer, but the Japanese did, and that was the end of much of the U.S. consumer electronics industry.

title: Tencent Doubles Stake in Universal Music Group
summary: Deal bolsters Chinese internet giant's growing presence in the record industry and its exposure to some of the biggest names in music. Tencent Holdings Ltd. is doubling its stake in the music giant behind Ariana Grande and Billie Eilish.

title: 10 Fashion Forward Holiday Gifts To Feel Good About
summary: This season, the most stylish gift you can give is one that gives back.. When shopping for a fashion fan, it's tempting to search for: an 'It' bag, a trendy shoe or a statement dress. But this year, the spirit has shifted, towards shopping smarter by supporting businesses that consider the wellbeing of their employees, the environment and the world at large. From an upcycled jacket that results in a tree being planted to a cashmere-lined slipper that sends a blanket to Save The Children, we've gathered our favorite pieces from brands that put philanthropy on their list. Check out the full list below and check back with WSJ. throughout the holiday season for more gift guides.

title: Margaret Chase Smith's Legacy Is Contested
summary: The moderate Republican got along with Democrats, but this did little to change what happened in Congress.. Peggy Noonan supplies an impressive list of "Mrs. Smith's Tips for New Lawmakers" (Declarations, Dec. 12) in her continued reminiscing about former Republican Sen. Margaret Chase Smith. Ms. Noonan admires Smith for her courage in standing up early to Sen. Joe McCarthy in 1950 as well as her moderation, wisdom, honesty and forthrightness-all qualities sorely needed in Congress today. Ms. Noonan hopes that newcomers to Congress in 2021 will emulate Smith.

title: More Hunting Is Good News for Wildlife Conservation
summary: The sale of hunting licenses, tags and stamps is also the primary source of funding for state wildlife agencies.. In "Hunting Aims for a Comeback in Locked-Down Michigan" (Cross Country, Nov. 28), Megan Keller notes that hunters are conservationists of a sort, as wildlife agencies use hunting to control wildlife populations that no longer have normal predators. Not mentioned is that the sale of hunting licenses, tags and stamps is also the primary source of funding for state wildlife agencies. Plus, the Pittman-Robertson Act imposes an 11% tax on the sale of firearms, ammunition and archery equipment, and directs much of the proceeds to fund wildlife conservation. Without hunting, wildlife conservation programs in the U.S. would collapse.

title: 'Four Corners' Don't Make Coach Dean Smith a Square
summary: North Carolina's basketball maven favored the shot clock and a fast game.. Fred Barnes's review of Paul Westhead's "The Speed Game" (Bookshelf, Dec. 16) diminishes CoachDean Smith by writing that he "favored" the "four corners" stalling tactic, in contrast to Mr. Westhead's speed offense. Smith popularized the four corners and used it some, but he didn't favor it or any other stall. He favored the shot clock and a fast game. When he faced Coach Westhead and Loyola Marymount in the 1988 NCAA tournament, his Tar Heels ran them off the court, 123-97.

title: FDA Panel Backs Moderna's Vaccine
summary: Food and Drug Administration is expected to grant emergency authorization by late Friday. A Food and Drug Administration advisory panel recommended Thursday that Moderna Inc.'s Covid-19 vaccine be cleared for broad use, setting the stage for the FDA to grant an expected emergency-use authorization by late Friday.

title: Caught Between Police and Protesters, Macron's Centrist Balancing Act Falls Apart
summary: Resume Subscription. PARIS-President Emmanuel Macron rose to power on a platform of "neither right, nor left." But now, after years straddling France's political divide, he is facing a national crisis that demands he pick a side.

title: Helping Workers Displaced By the Covid-19 Economy
summary: Job retraining programs have been largely ineffective in the past, but new private and public initiatives are using innovative strategies to assist the unemployed.. Nine months into the Covid-19 pandemic, with millions of Americans still out of work and the nation hurtling into what most economists agree will be a period of sustained economic disruption, Washington has largely ignored worker retraining.

title: The Pride and Strain of Being a First-Generation College Student
summary: My feelings of inadequacy and anxiety turned to strength when I realized that my experience could help other students. The first thing I remember feeling when I set foot on my college campus was inadequate.

title: Virgin Galactic, FedEx, Tesla: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: U.S stock futures were muted after the S&P 500 yesterday hit another record. Here's what we are watching as markets kick into gear Friday.

title: North Korea's Economy Hit Harder Than It Has Been in Decades
summary: Kim Jong Un's regime has further isolated the country due to the Covid-19 pandemic, and trade with China has plunged. SEOUL-North Korea's all-out push to halt the coronavirus has exacted a brutal blow to its already-tattered economy, contributing to a slide that will likely be the worst in a generation.

title: Abortion, Guns and Trump: A Church Group Tries to Navigate America's Divisions
summary: Calvary Christian Reformed in suburban Michigan seeks understanding through dialogue; 'my soul is hurting'. WYOMING, Mich.-The evening after Election Day, Mark and Nick Elders gathered nearly a dozen members of Calvary Christian Reformed Church in suburban Grand Rapids over Zoom. The brothers asked each person to reveal which presidential candidate they voted for and why.

title: Teachers Vie for Covid-19 Vaccine Priority
summary: Some argue educators should be among the first in line after front-line health-care workers and residents of long-term care facilities. Coronavirus vaccines rolled out across the nation this week for front-line health-care workers and residents of long-term care facilities. Teachers and school staff are vying for one of the first spots in line behind them.

title: China to Vaccinate 50 Million With Its Covid-19 Shots
summary: Country gears up for a large-scale rollout of Sinopharm and Sinovac vaccines in coming weeks. China plans to inoculate 50 million people with two experimental homegrown Covid-19 vaccines before February's Lunar New Year holiday season, leading up to vaccinations for the broader public by spring, people familiar with the matter said.

title: At Stanford, and in Women's College Basketball, Tara VanDerveer Stands Alone
summary: A head coach hits a history-making mark amid a pandemic-disrupted season. The first victory? Tara VanDerveer remembers the essential details. The year was 1978, VanDerveer's inaugural season on the sideline as the head coach of the University of Idaho women's basketball team. It was a close contest, versus Northern Montana, but as the clock wound down, VanDerveer grew confident they'd win. She instructed her team to play good defense, and importantly, not to foul.

title: For U.S. Economy This Winter, a Freeze and Then a Thaw
summary: The beginning of winter will be miserable for the U.S. economy, but things could be looking much brighter by March. With a worsening Covid-19 crisis sending a new wave of caution across the country, the beginning of winter will be a dark time for the U.S. economy. But by the time winter draws to a close, it could be rebounding more swiftly than seems imaginable.

title: How CIOs in 2020 Rallied Their Companies Around Remote Work
summary: IT experts say their responsibility around remote work didn't end at enabling technology. Chief information officers in 2020 have had to manage the effects of the coronavirus pandemic by quickly rolling out technology and overseeing new ways of working that will likely continue through next year.

title: U.S. Blacklists China's Top Chip Maker, Escalating Tech Fight
summary: SMIC among more than 60 Chinese institutions added to the entity list restricting access to American technology. The Trump administration is adding China's largest manufacturer of computing chips to an export blacklist, restricting the company's access to high-end technology over its alleged links to the Chinese military.

title: Logistics Set for Moderna Covid-19 Vaccine's Rollout
summary: The operation is supposed to be bigger than the Pfizer rollout and will build on the U.S. government's strategy used during the H1N1 pandemic. Federal officials are taking a page from the playbook used during the H1N1 pandemic in plans to speed vials of Moderna Inc.'s Covid-19 vaccine to thousands of locations if the shot is cleared for use by U.S. regulators.

title: How Tour de France Winners Secured Early Vaccines
summary: The UAE Team is due to receive the Chinese Sinopharm shot in Abu Dhabi in January. Winning the Tour de France was just about the craziest thing the UAE cycling team could imagine doing in the middle of a global health crisis. Even as the squad rolled onto the Champs-Élysées with the leader's yellow jersey last September, they could hardly believe they had pulled it off.

title: How Covid-19 Has Reshaped the Economy's Balance Sheet
summary: The economy has a lot of new debt but even more cash, making a 'balance-sheet recession' less likely than after 2008. After the 2008 crisis, households and firms spent years rebuilding their finances in what economist Richard Koo dubbed a "balance-sheet recession." Debt levels have jumped again this time round, but on closer reading, the books tell a more positive story.

title: Eaton's CFO Looks Back on 71 Acquisitions, 50 Sales Over His Tenure
summary: Richard Fearon played a role in shaping Eaton as a power-management company. Eaton Corp. PLC's finance chief Richard Fearon has managed 71 acquisitions and 50 sales since he began his tenure in April 2002, reshaping the portfolio of a business that was once known for making vehicle parts. Eaton, which operates out of Beachwood, Ohio, has expanded to become a power-management company that also manufactures products such as industrial clutches, motors and fuel pumps for a range of industries.

title: State Party Democrats Look to Avoid Obama-Era Repeat
summary: Focus is on organizing around local and state races that are crucial to controlling more levers of power. STATE DEMOCRATIC PARTIES try a new playbook to create sustained engagement among voters and small-dollar donors. "The fundamental mission of the next four years is to build on the last four rather than crashing and burning like Democrats did in 2009-10," said Ben Wikler, chairman of the Wisconsin Democratic Party, referring to the party's widespread losses after President Barack Obama's victory. Democrats failed across the country to flip statehouses in the November election, though in Wisconsin the party has clawed back some posts in the past few years, including winning the governorship and narrowing Democrats' deficit on the State Supreme Court. Wikler's party is encouraging supporters to sign up to donate monthly so it can organize around local and lower-profile state races that are crucial to building the party's bench and controlling more levers of power.

title: Infrastructure-Investment Binge Will Continue-Even Without Washington
summary: Outlook for a sweeping infrastructure bill in the Biden administration is uncertain, but private-sector deals and fundraising are humming. As the Biden administration prepares to take over in Washington, hopes for a sweeping infrastructure bill are running high. But even if one does come to pass, Wall Street isn't counting on getting a big piece of it.

title: 2020 by The Numbers: Test Your Knowledge
summary: Look back over the year with Jo Craven McGinty. This year, The Numbers examined topics ranging from the lifespan of a centuries-old animal to a trendy alcoholic beverage that swallowed its market; from Americans who expatriated to green-card holders who became citizens; from the spread of Covid-19 to the scourge of plastic bags. Here's a quiz to test regular readers' recollections of The Numbers.

title: In Lockerbie, Downing of Pan Am Flight 103 Still Casts a Long Shadow
summary: Scars remain in the Scottish town where 11 people were killed by debris from the 1988 bombing. LOCKERBIE, Scotland-The sky rained fire on a chill December night here in 1988. Karen Gass was 26 years old at the time. She didn't realize at first what was happening.

title: Five Years On, China's World Bank Challenger Has Fallen Short of Lofty Predictions
summary: Resume Subscription. In a little over a month, the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank will be five years old. Back then, the nascent China-organized multinational lender was described as a challenger to the Asian Development Bank and even the World Bank.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: HHS Pick Becerra Plans Focus on Virus-if He Gets Job
summary: Some Republicans say he is too focused on abortion rights and too inexperienced in health care. WASHINGTON-Xavier Becerra already knows what he would do as Health and Human Services secretary.

title: Tesla Joins the S&P 500: Five Things to Watch
summary: Traders are bracing for big swings in stock, options markets ahead of electric-car maker's addition to index Monday. Tesla Inc. will officially join the S&P 500 Monday, likely precipitating a frenzied Friday afternoon in markets.

title: Kidnapped Nigerian Boys Reunited With Families
summary: Reunion comes a week after militants stormed their dormitories, as questions remain over who perpetrated the crime and why the students were set free. KATSINA, Nigeria-More than 300 Nigerian boys were reunited with their parents Friday, a week after militants stormed their dormitories in one of the largest kidnappings of schoolchildren in history.
